answers.answer: Hi, I'm not a medical professional, just a parent of a child with diabetes.  Our endocrinologist told us that any reading over 250 is an automatic diagnosis of diabetes, so you are right to be concerned.  Scores can go back to normal on their own because things like adrenalin release from physical activity cause the muscles to absorb glucose from the bloodstream without the need for insulin.  Being overweight and having diabetes is only relevant to Type 2 diabetes, the concerns you are expressing are about Type 1.  I don't know of any known links between gestational diabetes and the child getting diabetes, but maybe one of my fellow staff members here might know.  Research has also noted that there is a genetic component to diabetes, but there is more to it than that.  There is some environmental factor which also seems to be a trigger.  But remember, I'm not a medical professional, I just read a lot.I would ask your doctor to do a more thorough diabetes screening.  The simplest of those is a urine test, the more complex involves a blood test to check for antibodies.  As far as I'm concerned, you can't be too cautious when it comes to the health of your children.

question: I have a 10 year old daughter,I tested her a couple of times and random tests were 218,114,179.Her two hour level was 275.It seems to come down to within normal range on it's own,I haven't tested her fasting level yet and will be doing that in the morning.She is not overweight.She is about 4ft 8in and weighs 68 pounds,very active.Eats well.How concerned should I be with these levels,what questions should I ask her doctor?We do have diabetes in our family mostly type 2,I had gestational diabetes with all three of my pregnancies the last one I was on insulin for.Thank you Heather
title: My 10 year old daughter has had some high readings (not diagnosed)
